awd_titl_txt: Metallic Properties of the Isotopes of Hydrogen
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract
The hydrogen atom is composed of a single proton and a single electron bonded together.  The deuterium nucleus is composed of a proton and neutron, so twice the mass of hydrogen. The objective of this research is to study the properties of the hydrogen isotopes: hydrogen, deuterium, and hydrogen deuteride in the metallic phases (tritium is omitted as it is radioactive), collectively referred to as the hydrogens.  In general isotopic effects of elements are small, of order a percent or two. In the hydrogens, the mass ratio of D2 to H2 is 200% and the impact on the behavior can be very large. For example, one of the important quantum aspects of hydrogen is the zero-point energy or motion in the condensed matter phase. The consequence is that in the zero temperature limit, the atoms or moleules are not in fixed positions in lattice sites, but have motion around these sites.  Such materials have very low temperatures of solidification (molecular hydrogen, about 14 K; deuterium about 18 K). Helium is even more quantum than the molecular hydrogens and does not have a solid state, remaining liquid to T= 0K.  Atomic hydrogen itself is predicted to have a liquid ground state. The research team plans to study the effects of high pressure on the hydrogens. The team has already shown experimentally that hydrogen deuteride, which is a stable molecule, becomes unstable at a pressure of ~200 GPa, dissociating and recombining to form a stable mixture of HD, D2 an H2. Thus, in this research the properties of the isotopes at ultra high pressures and low temperatures shall be studied.

Technical Abstract
The program of research is to study the properties of the hydrogens at pressure where they are metallic. In the research program it has already been shown that hydrogen becomes a metal at ~500 GPa. It is expected that the pressure will be higher for deuterium as, due to its larger mass, molecular deuterium will have smaller zero-point energy and a larger binding energy.  HD should have many surprises as above ~200 GPa it becomes a mixture of 0.5 HD and 0.25 (H2+D2). It may require a pressure of 500 GPa to dissociate the H2 molecules, but the HD may become unstable at still a lower pressure. Surprises are expected in this study. Once the isotopes are metallized, the ground state will be studied by xray analysis. One of the intriguing predictions for hydrogen is that it may be a room temperature superconductor, which will be studied. It has also been predicted to be metastable, i.e. it may remain in the metallic state when the pressure is relieved. The metastability of the isotopes shall be studied by reducing the pressure at low temperature, then raising the temperature until the sample converts back to the molecular phase.  It may be that hydrogen is not metastable, but deuterium is, due to its smaller zero point energy. Finally,  a pressure scale for ultrahigh pressures will be developed. There is no good scale at 500+GPa.  A study of the shift of the fluorescence line in nitrogen vacancy nano-diamond can lead to a new pressure calibration scale.

por.por_cntn:
In past experiments we established that hydrogen could be metallized at the enormous pressure of almost 500 GPa (5 megabars). In the current research project we had several objectives: 1. Repeat the creation of metallic hydrogen (MH) in the laboratory, and study metastability MH. Objective 2: study superconducting critical temperature Tc of MH. Objective 3: study metallization of deuterium and HD. Objective 4. Study the phase of MH at low temperature—solid or liquid H. Objective 5. Study the use of nitrogen vacancy (NV) in diamond for pressure determination. 

Objective 1 was successfully carried out and an article has just been published. Objective 2 is partially executed, but we need more data. At a pressure of 480 GPa hydrogen is metallic and resistance starts to fall at a temperature of about 270 K, but the transition is broad (probably due to pressure gradients) and goes to zero at much lower temperature, shown in Fig.1. The Meissner effect has to be studied before publication. Objective 3 is currently underway: in one failed run the pressurized sample leaked out at a low pressure; in another the diamonds in the diamond anvil cell (DAC) failed at a pressure of 370 GPa. We are currently starting a new run. Objective 4 is deferred to the future. In objective 5 we found that NV diamond cannot be used for ultra-high pressure determination (no publication).

We shall now focus on objective 1, metastability of MH. The plan was to first establish that pressurized hydrogen is metallic, then at low temperature reduce the pressure to zero. If the sample remains metallic it is metastable at ambient conditions; then increase the temperature until it converts to molecular hydrogen. 

 With increasing pressure, hydrogen transitions from a transparent insulator to a black, non-reflecting material, to a shiny reflecting metal, shown in Fig. 2, taken from an earlier experiment.  Loading of a sample is critical and in the current experiment the sample diameter when first sealed in the gasket was much smaller than the uncompressed hole shown in Fig. 3a.  The sealed sample was surrounded by the confining rhenium gasket, accidentally covered with black slag. At the metallization pressure the sample was thus very small in diameter but sufficient in size to study and measure the reflectance. Measurements of the reflectance of the sample as a function of wavelength could be fit to a Drude free-electron model, establishing that the hydrogen had transitioned to atomic MH at a pressure between 477 and 492 GPa.

In our diamond anvil cell we can measure the pressure by means of a calibrated turn of a drive screw. We change by increments of 1/8th of a turn, so 8 increments is a full turn of the screw. The larger the number of turns of the screw the higher the force on the sample and the higher the pressure. When the turns are reversed the force and pressure are reduced. In Fig.4 we show the MH as the pressure is being released. In this case when the hydrogen was metallic (see Fig.3c, not shown in Fig. 4) we set the force measuring device to zero. Thus, in Fig. 4 (a) the MH is still observable with the force reduced by 16/8 turns. With further turns the MH disappears (converts to molecular hydrogen) and does not reflect light as the hole closed down. Fig. 4c corresponds to zero pressure. Clearly from this figure, we see that MH is metastable as it still exists at 16/8 release. However, it does not exist at zero pressure. Thus, MH is metastable but not at zero pressure in the low temperature limit. 

There are theoretical reasons to believe that metallic deuterium, with its smaller zero-point energy,  is more likely to be metastable than hydrogen, as well as having a higher critical temperature. Thus, experiments to metallize deuterium are important for possible applications of the hydrogen isotope. For example, If supeconducting at room temperature and wires could be made of metallic D, then wiring of the electrical grid in the US would save about 20% of the energy, that is otherwise dissipated in normal resistive wires. Superconducting magnets made of MD would not need liquid helium and would render magnetic resonance imaging accessible all over the world, where helium is not available. If scaled up in quantity MD would be a powerful rocket propellant able to place satellites in orbit with a single stage rocket.
